name: Count Basie
description:
'''William James''' "'''Count'''" '''Basie''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|eɪ|s|i}}; August 21, 1904 – April 26, 1984) was an American [[jazz]] pianist, organist, bandleader, and composer. In 1935, he formed the [[Count Basie Orchestra]], and in 1936 took them to [[Chicago]] for a long engagement and their first recording. He led the group for almost 50 years, creating innovations like the use of two "split" tenor saxophones, emphasizing the rhythm section, riffing with a big band, using arrangers to broaden their sound, his minimalist piano style, and others.

Many musicians came to prominence under his direction, including the tenor saxophonists [[Lester Young]] and [[Herschel Evans]], the guitarist [[Freddie Green]], trumpeters [[Buck Clayton]] and [[Harry "Sweets" Edison]], plunger trombonist [[Al Grey]], and singers [[Jimmy Rushing]], [[Helen Humes]], [[Dennis Rowland]], [[Thelma Carpenter]], and [[Joe Williams (jazz singer)|Joe Williams]].

As a composer, Basie is known for writing such [[jazz standard]]s as "[[Blue and Sentimental]]", "[[Jumpin' at the Woodside]]" and "[[One O'Clock Jump]]".
